content.webTitle: Canada will take extra time bringing in Syrian refugees in order to 'do it right'

fields.headline: Canada will take extra time bringing in Syrian refugees in order to 'do it right'
fields.bodyText: Canada’s new Liberal government has announced that it will not meet its target of bringing 25,000 Syrian refugees into the country by the end of this year – but pledged to resettle the full number by February with a focus on accepting families, women at risk, and members of the LGBTQ community. “This is a happy day and this is an important day for Canada,” said the immigration minister, John McCallum, who released details of the plan on Tuesday, saying the country will “welcome them with a smile”. After a landslide electoral victory in October, the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, was left scrambling to meet a campaign pledge to resettle 25,000 refugees by 31 December. McCallum conceded that only 10,000 refugees will arrive by that date, but said a further 15,000 will reach the country by the end of February, adding that the government was taking the extra time to “do it right”. “A smile alone is not sufficient. We want them to have a roof over their head. We want them to have support,” he said. Canada’s announcement stands in contrast to the alarming political rhetoric from politicians in the US, where at least 30 state governors have said they will refuse to accept Syrian refugees, and Republican frontrunner Donald Trump has described those fleeing civil war violence as a potential “Trojan horse” for Islamist militants. But the Liberal plan has also drawn some criticism after it emerged that single men will – at least initially – only be accepted if they were traveling with their family or could prove that they had been targeted due to their sexual orientation. The executive director of the Canadian Council of Refugees, Janet Dench, said Tuesday’s announcement was “long overdue”. But she said she had misgivings about the exclusion of unaccompanied men, which she suggested reinforced stereotypes about Syrian men as “inherently dangerous”. Refugees will be vetted by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and by a handful of Canadian agencies – a process the federal public safety minister, Ralph Goodale, called a “robust, multi-layered” verification. The refugees will be identified and processed overseas by the UNHCR and Canadian officials in Jordan and Lebanon. Those two countries will also assist in the resettlement, including by securing exit visas. Privately chartered planes – with military transport assisting if necessary – will bring them to Canada. On arrival, they will be resettled in communities across the country. Temporary housing on military bases is available for short-term housing if needed. It is estimated the plan will cost C$678m over six years. Despite initial misgivings about the fast-tracked intake from politicians in Saskatchewan and Quebec, provincial premiers have supported the government plan. “This is not a federal project, this is not even a government project, it’s a national project for all Canadians,” said McCallum. Trudeau’s predecessor Stephen Harper had refused to accept more Syrian refugees, even after the issue became a key electoral issue when it emerged that Alan Kurdi – the Syrian boy whose body washed ashore in Turkey attracted worldwide attention – had family in Canada. During the campaign Harper’s Conservative party was accused of attempting to use Muslim immigration as a wedge issue, but opinion polls have shown that Canadian attitudes towards refugees are still somewhat more welcoming than those in the US and UK. James Hollifield, an expert on refugees and immigration with the Washington-based Wilson Center, said that Canada tends to be a “big outlier” compared with other western nations in its openness to accepting immigrants and refugees. Hollifield said that contrast was due to a broadly successful immigration policy, a clear demand for immigrants in the workforce, and a geography that buffers it from the effects of illegal immigration. But he warned that adding national security concerns to the ramped-up rhetoric of a US presidential election cycle had created a “perfect storm” to politicize the refugee debate. “Anything that brings chaos, uncertainty, division in the west and pits a large Muslim community against western societies in which they have settled, that’s exactly what [Islamists] want,” he said. “Unfortunately, a lot of politicians have taken the bait hook, line and sinker.” Trudeau has called on Canadians to reject racism, but the country has seen a spike in anti-Muslim hate incidents in recent weeks. An Ontario mosque was firebombed. A Muslim woman in Toronto was attacked, punched in the stomach and verbally assaulted by two men. An Ottawa woman received a note in her mailbox with the message: “Canada is no place for immigrants and terrorists. Go back home.” Amira Elghawaby, with the National Council of Canadian Muslims, said that Canada has an “undercurrent” of Islamophobia which surfaces in the wake of events like those in Paris. “A small minority of people will act on their ignorance,” she said. But she said that many Canadians are ready to open their arms to the waves of refugees about to start arriving in the country next week. “What I’m seeing right now across Canada is an incredible groundswell of love and compassion and support for the refugees,” she said. “It’s really quite incredible.”
